properties.areaDesc: Clear Lake/Southern Lake County; Southern Sacramento Valley; Motherlode; Northern Sacramento Valley; Shasta Lake Area / Northern Shasta County; West Slope Northern Sierra Nevada; Northern San Joaquin Valley; Western Plumas County/Lassen Park; Mountains Southwestern Shasta County to Northern Lake County; Burney Basin / Eastern Shasta County; Carquinez Strait and Delta; Central Sacramento Valley; Northeast Foothills/Sacramento Valley
properties.headline: Special Weather Statement issued January 19 at 3:30AM PST by NWS Sacramento CA
properties.description:
Pacific storm brings precipitation into the Coastal Range, Shasta
mountains and northern portions of the Sacramento Valley Monday
night. Widespread precipitation and breezy conditions then spread
over most of interior Northern California Tuesday morning. This
will make for a wet commute on Tuesday with slick roads and
possible longer travel times. Snow spreads into the mountains of
Western Plumas and Northern Sierra Nevada Tuesday morning with
heaviest snow expected late morning through early evening. Chain
controls could be in effect for the Trans-Sierra passes, and
motorists heading up into the mountains Tuesday should check the
latest road conditions. Decreasing showers expected Tuesday night,
with lingering snow showers possible over the Sierra Nevada into
Wednesday morning.

Snow levels forecast to be around 4000 to 5500 feet Monday night
into Tuesday, lowering to 3500 to 4500 feet Tuesday night into
Wednesday morning. Snow fall amounts of 4 to 12 inches expected
above 5000 feet with locally higher amounts over Lassen Peak.
Forecast rainfall amounts in the Central Valley range from under
a tenth in the Northern San Joaquin Valley to above half an inch
in the Northern Sacrament Valley. Around an inch or rain is
expected in the wetter foothills locations.

NWSheadline: Wet Weather returns late Monday into early Wednesday
